abstract.text: An object that represents a push-to-talk channel manager.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: You must create a channel manager upon launching your app, otherwise the system tears down channels and their ability to receive push notifications. By providing a
, an app can rejoin or leave a previously active channel the system knows about. Once the channel resoration process completes, the system provides a
result in the system returning the same shared instance, so store the channel manager in an instance variable.

abstract.text: Display the system user interface for your appâ€™s Push to Talk services.
An object that represents a push-to-talk channel manager.
The unique identifier of the active channel for the app.
Creates a channel manager with the configuration you specify.
Leaves a channel with the identifier.
Begins an audio transmission with the channel identifer you specify.
Joins a channel with the identifier and descriptor you specify.
Maps supported accessory button events to actions that begin and end transmission.
Sets the active remote participant with the channel identifier.
Sets the channel description.
Sets the service connection status.
Sets the audio transmission mode for the channel you specify.
Stops an audio transmission with the channel identifer you specify.
A type that represents the channel restoration behavior.
Build a walkie-talkie style app with system user interface controls.

doc://com.apple.pushtotalk/documentation.title: Creating a Push to Talk app

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
